text:
It’s the last weekend to see City Theatre’s “Love Alone.” 12:00 a.m. Friday, Oct. 16, 2015 | Filed in: Entertainment 
The City Theatre’s “Love Alone” 
8 p.m. Saturday and 3 p.m. Sunday. $15-$25. 3823 Airport Blvd. Suie D. 512-524-2870, citytheatreaustin.org. Jay Janner Polyphonic Spree will perform Sunday at Emo’s. 
The Austin premiere of this play by Deborah Salem Smith pulls no punches as it lays bare the emotions of two families dealing with a routine medical procedure gone tragically wrong. When Helen’s lesbian partner of 20 years dies unexpectedly, she and her daughter want answers. An ensuing lawsuit transforms the lives of both the patient’s family, who are confused by the hospital’s silence, and the doctor charged with her care. — Ari Auber

In their 15-year run, the Dallas choral rockers have shed their choir robes and reinvented themselves as “The Fragile Army” (and the greatest “Rocky Horror Picture Show” cover band in history). Now the band refocuses on “The Beginning Stages Of…,” their debut album recorded in two days in 2000. It was a rebellion against guitar rock and a statement of purpose for bandleader Tim DeLaughter, who was grieving a friend and former collaborator. By the time the band toured the album, their stage spectacle had eclipsed the original arrangements. For this show, the band will play the entire album in sequence. Calliope Musicals opens. $23-$25. 7 p.m. doors. 2015 E. Riverside Drive. emosaustin.com. — Deborah Sengupta Stith 
Art Jeanne Claire van Ryzin Organized by the Americas Society in New York, “Moderno: Design for Living in Brazil, Mexico and Venezuela” is at the Blanton Museum of Art through Jan. 17. 
“Moderno: Design for Living in Brazil, Mexico, and Venezuela, 1940-78” 
10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesday-Friday, 11 a.m to 5 p.m. Saturday and 1 to 5 p.m. Sunday. Through Jan. 17. $5-$9. Blanton Museum of Art, 200 E. Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. 512-471-7324, blantonmuseum.org. 
Forget “Mad Men” style and its North American exclusiveness. Modernism was a world-wide phenomena. Organized by the Americas Society in New York, “Moderno” is the first exhibit to examine how design transformed the domestic landscape of Latin America during a period marked by huge societal and political shifts. And the Blanton Museum’s presentation augments the more than 130 pieces of furniture, ceramics, metalwork, textiles and graphic design with a selection of Brazilian, Mexican and Venezuelan paintings. — Jeanne Claire van Ryzin
